title: Remote sensing applications for monitoring restoration outcomes in boreal forestry-drained peatlands - Reviewed applications and future potential
abstract:
•Remote sensing has high potential to monitor the recovery of restored peatlands. •Methodology selection depends on metrics of interest and aimed monitoring coverage. •Monitoring can include hydrology, vegetation, topography and peat properties. •Greenhouse gas exchanges can be modelled with remote data or uncrewed probing. •Tree cover distracts the remote sensing of forestry-drained restoration sites. 
 Peatland restoration can halt biodiversity loss and organic soil degradation and mitigate climate change. Monitoring of restoration impacts requires novel approaches that can be scaled to large site networks. On a smaller scale, the restoration practitioners would likewise benefit from spatially and temporally comprehensive and objective monitoring data. This narrative review compiles potential remote sensing methods for practical monitoring of the ecohydrological processes in restoration of forestry-drained boreal peatlands to support and complement conventional ground monitoring approaches that are restricted by spatial coverage. Remote sensing provides tools for tracking the changes in soil surface moisture, water flow routes, vegetation cover and structure, topography, peat depth and greenhouse gas emissions. We emphasize that the suitable indicators of restoration success, platforms and sensors should be tailored to specific restoration cases with their own initial site conditions and restoration targets. The choice of spatial and temporal resolutions of data is defined by the scale and change rate of the restoration indicators. Data acquisition campaigns and selection of existing datasets require meticulous planning due to seasonal changes in hydrology and vegetation. We also compiled practical experiences on selecting remote sensing tools and ensuring satisfactory data quality to facilitate the implementation of remote-sensing-based monitoring. Finally, we provide recommendations on how the rapid development of remote sensing technology, encompassing new uncrewed applications and novel sensors on conventional platforms, can offer a range of monitoring tools to cater to the growing needs for spatially comprehensive data amounts assessing peatland restoration success in boreal conditions.

authors: Wolfgang Wagner;Bernhard Bauer-Marschallinger;Florian Roth;Tobias Raiger-Stachl;Christoph Reimer;Niall McCormick;Patrick Matgen;Marco Chini;Yu Li;Sandro Martinis;Marc Wieland;Franziska Kraft;Davide Festa;Muhammed Hassaan;Mark Edwin Tupas;Jie Zhao;Michaela Seewald;Michael Riffler;Luca Molini;Richard Kidd
title: The fully-automatic Sentinel-1 Global Flood Monitoring service: Scientific challenges and future directions
abstract:
•We set up a fully-automatic global monitoring service for flood mapping: GFM. •Flood and likelihood maps from three SAR-algorithms are combined in an ensemble. •Models are based on geophysical considerations on SAR’s sensitivity to flood. •A global multi-year SAR datacube allows robust and up-to-date models and parameters. •GFM output is joined by context-layers and is freely available in near-real-time. 
 Sentinel-1 is a unique resource for global flood monitoring, providing systematic, weather-independent Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imagery with unprecedented coverage. To overcome limitations of on-demand flood mapping services that depend on human operators to collect and interpret satellite images, a fundamentally new approach was adopted by the Global Flood Monitoring (GFM) service. This service, which was launched in 2021 as part of the Copernicus Emergency Management Service (CEMS), processes all Sentinel-1 land images acquired in VV polarisation fully automatically in near-real time. This article presents the first comprehensive analysis of GFM’s scientific achievements and challenges during its initial years of operation. To map floods reliably under diverse environmental conditions, GFM combines three complementary flood-mapping algorithms with reference water datasets to differentiate flooded areas from permanent and seasonal water bodies. The service also offers a novel flood-likelihood layer and contextual information to highlight areas where flood mapping is unreliable or not feasible. These data layers were derived from a global 20 m backscatter datacube containing approximately 379 billion land surface pixels. This datacube also made it possible to generate the first global Sentinel-1 flood archive (2015 to present). Our performance analysis shows that GFM typically delivers flood maps within five hours of image acquisition. However, a significant percentage of floods may go undetected due to coverage gaps. Initial evaluation results show that good accuracies are achieved for larger-scale floods and regions in the temperate and tropical zones, while accuracies are lower for smaller-scale floods and arid environments. The GFM service will continue to improve service quality by enhancing flood detection capabilities using improved algorithms and additional data, such as the VH channel from Sentinel-1 or L-band data from the upcoming ROSE-L mission.

title: Modeling, prediction, and retrieval of surface soil moisture from InSAR closure phase
abstract:
•We present a multi-layer model linking soil moisture to SAR measurements. •We analyze the impacts of soil moisture anomalies, radar frequency, and soil texture. •We propose a proof-of-concept algorithm to retrieve soil moisture from InSAR data. 
 We present a discretized, multi-layer soil moisture model that links soil moisture variability to single-look SAR measurements. Our model reveals distinct closure phase signatures arising from variation of soil moisture, radar frequencies, and soil textures. Specifically, our model predicts that positive asymmetric soil moisture anomalies produce positive closure phase step-changes, and negative asymmetric anomalies yield negative closure phase step-changes, consistent with observed data. Additionally, our analysis reveals that low-frequency radar (e.g., L-band) exhibits heightened sensitivity to the vertical distribution of soil moisture. We identify an approximate transfer function between soil moisture anomalies and closure phase responses and introduce a scalable algorithm for retrieving the InSAR Soil Moisture Index, a relative soil moisture product. We demonstrate the retrieval algorithm in two diverse environments: the Mojave Desert and the Central Valley in California. Good agreements between the derived InSAR Soil Moisture Index, in situ soil moisture measurements, and SMAP/Sentinel-1 soil moisture measurements highlight the potential for large-scale soil moisture monitoring using InSAR closure phase.

title: Extraction of line Surge Arresters from UAV LiDAR point clouds based on multi-view structural features
abstract:
•A structure-guided method identifies small Line Surge Arresters (LSAs) in 3D laser scans of power pylons. •Candidate line segments are selected using structural width and density estimation. •A swarm-optimization algorithm extracts LSAs via structural consistency measures. •The method achieves 98.28% identification accuracy and 90.11% F1-score on 3,571 pylons. •A public dataset of 896 annotated arresters supports 3D protection device research. 
 Line Surge Arresters (LSAs) play a vital role in protecting power transmission systems from overvoltage, and obtaining their 3D information is crucial for precise reconstruction of power lines and intelligent planning of inspection routes. Current studies mainly rely on image-based methods for LSAs recognition. Unmanned Aerial Vehicle-mounted Light Detection and Ranging is an effective way to obtain 3D information of transmission corridors. However, accurately extracting LSAs from point clouds remains a significant challenge because of small physical size, sparse point distribution, and structural similarity to other components. In this study, an LSAs extraction method is proposed using the structural features. The method initially separates pylon and power line components using established techniques and further clusters the power line points into Single Power Line (SPL) as analysis unit, representing potential installation locations of the LSAs. For each SPL, this study proposes a structure-based method to identify the presence of LSAs. A width-based filtering criterion is applied to exclude SPLs without LSAs coarsely, retaining only those with potential LSA presence. For the retained SPLs, kernel density estimation is employed to capture the structural characteristics in case of LSA existence, thereby precisely preserving the SPLs containing LSAs. Following the identifying process, a Particle Swarm Optimization based segmentation method is proposed to achieve precise extraction of the LSAs. A structure-consistency-driven objective function is constructed using proposed Transmission Compactness Index and Axial Uniformity Index to model the geometric differences between LSAs and neighboring components. Based on this objective function, the optimal segmentation plane is searched to separate the LSAs from other components. The proposed method was evaluated on a dataset covering 63 transmission lines with a total of 3,571 pylons. Results demonstrate that the method achieves an overall identification accuracy of 98.28 %, with extraction precision of 92.66 %, recall of 87.43 %, and F1-score of 90.11 %. Additionally, our method shows high efficiency with the average processing time per pylon of 3.82 s. Compared to existing general segmentation algorithms, the proposed approach offers significant improvements in extraction accuracy. To foster further research, we release a point cloud dataset for LSAs extraction, which will be publicly available at: https://github.com/c175044/Line-Surge-Arresters-datasets.

title: Free from manually defined potential regions: Large-scale mangrove monitoring based on self-supervised geospatially-aligned prototype learning
abstract:
•First self-supervised method for automatically generating potential mangrove regions to effectively bridge inland detection gaps. •Latest annually updated mangrove dataset in Australia spanning 2014 to 2023, setting a new benchmark for mangrove mapping. •Novel insight for conservation by revealing mangrove edge vulnerability and patch stability dynamics. 
 Mangroves are vital ecosystems that thrive in specific ecological niches, making it essential to identify areas of potential region for effective large-scale monitoring. However, existing methods for delineating potential mangrove regions are often either rigid or labor-intensive, frequently overlooking inland mangroves along tidal channels and lacking suitability for long-term analysis. Therefore, this study develops the self-supervised geospatially-aligned prototype learning (SGAPL) to automatically generate the potential mangrove regions based on scene-level labels. SGAPL integrates geo-grouped temporal inputs for deep feature extraction, geo-corrected prototype modeling with superpixel-aligned smoothing to enhance spatial completeness, and an adjacent-scene continuity strategy to improve the consistency of potential mangrove regions. We produced the scene-driven Australia mangrove maps (SAMM_14-23), which achieved an overall accuracy of 94.65 ±0.85%. The analysis based on the mangrove potential region generated by SGAPL revealed that more than 4000 ha of inland mangrove patches had been underestimated by traditional approaches. Analysis of SAMM_14-23 revealed two key patterns: (1) over 70% of mangrove changes occurred within a 50-meter buffer zone along patch boundaries, highlighting significant edge vulnerability; and (2) a clear inverse relationship between patch size and change rate, with patches larger than 4000 ha demonstrating high stability. SGAPL offers a novel framework for large-scale mangrove monitoring, addressing the long-standing gap in inland mangrove detection. The resulting SAMM_14-23 dataset provides comprehensive, up-to-date information to support targeted conservation efforts, particularly in edge protection and habitat connectivity, with direct relevance to multiple Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

title: A Data-Driven framework for pedestrian oriented route planning leveraging deep learning and spatial perception
abstract:
•Deep Learning (DL) models to detect and segment image features. •Street View perception prediction using 360° images for Mumbai and Paris. •A comprehensive geodatabase of perception for city of Mumbai. •Relationship analysis between built forms and perceptions. •A framework for perception-based navigation using GSVI. •Generalization of perception prediction across Mumbai and Paris. 
 Individuals make distinct walking choices based on the surrounding urban environment perceptions. Although a lot of work has been done in quantifying human perception of urban environment, existing research has not explored how the choices driven by perception can support walkability. This research aims to address this gap by proposing a framework that leverages 360-degree Google Street View Images (GSVIs), which serve as inputs to Deep Learning (DL) models. These models then extract informative features that contribute to the prediction of various perceptual attributes viz. beautiful, boring, safe, and lively collected through a primary survey. The attributes were integrated with road network at 100-meter intervals for the city of Mumbai, India. A multi-objective function is proposed to minimize the distance and maximize the perception to provide good routes. The DL models OCRNet and pretrained PPYOLOE + x achieved a high mIoU score of 72.13 %, and 51.4 %, respectively. Additionally, the state-of-art transformer-based model DINOv3 utilized for comparitive analysis and generalizability. The perception models also achieved a high accuracy of over 90%. Significant variations in routes were observed in diverse urban built-ups. The outcomes can support appropriate planning of urban spaces which can encourage walking, leading to reduction of carbon emissions.

explanation: 该研究论文探讨了华北平原PM2.5浓度变化对光散射特性的影响。研究发现，虽然PM2.5浓度降低，但由于二次有机气溶胶（SOA）的形成和颗粒物粒径的增长，导致光散射效率（MSE）增加，从而抵消了PM2.5降低带来的大气能见度改善。研究强调了硝酸铵和有机气溶胶在光散射中的作用，并提出了改进的回归模型以提高光散射预测的准确性。该研究与大气环境遥感技术密切相关，因为它涉及空气质量监测、大气成分分析以及颗粒物对大气能见度的影响。

authors: Aomeng Cai;Shuangshuang Zou;Guoqing Zhao;Weisi Wang;Yunfei Wu;Renjian Zhang;Qingxia Ma;Daizhou Zhang
title: Influence of particle growth and secondary aerosol formation on light scattering associated with PM<sub>2.5</sub> variability in the North China plain
abstract:
•NH4NO3was the primary contributor to σspat both high and low PM2.5levels, particularly during haze periods. •Primary organic aerosol contributions surpassed NH4NO3at medium PM2.5levels. •Large secondary organic aerosols formation under high O3conditions, cause particle size growth and then enhanced MSE. •The New Regression models improve the predictive accuracy of scattering by 7 %–21 %. 
 The light scattering properties of fine particulate matter (PM2.5) were investigated in a megacity on the North China Plain during periods of substantial PM2.5 variation. The results revealed a non-linear reduction in the scattering efficient (σsp) relative to decreases in PM2.5 concentrations. Ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3) was the primary contributor to σsp, accounting for 34.7 %–43.3 % at both high and low PM2.5 levels. However, primary organic aerosol (POA) became the largest contributor to σsp (31.5 %) at medium PM2.5 levels, with secondary organic aerosol (SOA) rising sharply by 13.9 %, collectively sustaining σsp and limiting its reduction. The scattering Ångström exponent (SAE) decreased from 2.1 ± 0.9 (high PM2.5 levels) by 31.1 %–50.5 % at medium and low levels, indicating a shift towards larger particle sizes as pollution levels declined. Strong negative correlations between SAE and the organic carbon/elemental carbon (OC/EC) ratio (r = −0.193, p < 0.01) at medium PM2.5 levels, as well as the mass scattering efficient (MSE) (r = −0.656, p < 0.01), testified the critical role of SOA formation in enhancing particle size and σsp under improved air quality conditions. Regression models based solely on aerosol components underestimated σsp, likely due to the exclusion of particle growth and SOA formation. Incorporating POA, SOA and SAE into σsp calculations significantly improved predictive accuracy by 7 %–21 %. These findings demonstrate that enhanced SOA formation and particle size growth increase MSE and effectively counteract reductions in σsp despite declining PM2.5 levels, thereby further hindering improvements in atmospheric visibility.

authors: Célia Alves;Estela D. Vicente;Teresa Nunes;Yago Cipoli;Isabella Charres;Eduardo Yubero;Nuria Galindo;Jiří Ryšavý;Anabela Leitão
title: Elemental and carbonaceous composition of PM<sub>10</sub> and its oxidative potential in schools in Luanda
abstract:
•PM10levels in Luanda schools often exceeded WHO guidelines, especially on weekdays. •Carbonaceous material made up 21.3 % of PM10, with a high OC/EC ratio of 2.26 ± 0.74. •Mineral dust, traffic, and industrial activities were key sources of elemental PM10. •Oxidative potential of PM10was driven by OC, WSOC, and transition metals. •Structural upgrades and dust control are needed to improve school air quality. 
 Chemical speciation and oxidative potential (OP) analysis of airborne particles in African schools has not been previously conducted. In this study, daily atmospheric particulate matter (PM10) sampling was carried out in classrooms of four primary schools in Luanda, Angola. Samples were analysed for elemental composition, organic and elemental carbon (OC and EC) and water-soluble organic carbon (WSOC). OP was measured using two acellular assays: dithiothreitol (DTT) and ascorbic acid (AA). PM10 concentrations ranged from 10.2 to 183 μg m−3, exceeding the WHO guideline on ∼70 % of days, with weekday averages (61.0 μg m−3) more than twice those recorded on Saturdays (26.2 μg m−3). Carbonaceous constituents accounted for 21.3 % of PM10 mass, with a consistent OC/EC ratio of 2.26 ± 0.74. On average, 77 % of OC was estimated to be secondary, while WSOC/OC ratios ranged from 0.15 to 0.90, averaging 0.42 ± 0.18. The most abundant elements were Ca, S, Cl, and K, with the highest concentrations observed in a school affected by structural issues and proximity to an unpaved road. Enrichment factor analysis revealed extremely high anthropogenic contributions for Br, S, Cl, Ni, Zn, Pb, Cu, V, and Cr, while correlations between elements indicated major sources such as resuspended mineral dust, vehicular emissions, fuel combustion, and industrial activities, with additional contributions from road dust, construction sites, and sea spray. Average OPAA values ranged from 1.36 to 2.21 nmol min−1 m−3, while OPDTT values spanned from 0.507 to 0.854 nmol min−1 m−3. OC, WSOC, and several transition metals were key contributors to OPDTT, whereas OPAA showed significant correlations only with Ni and Sr.

explanation: 该论文主要关注利用深度学习方法对长江流域极端高温事件进行亚季节尺度的预测。研究重点在于开发一种基于残差U-Net（Res-UNet）架构的确定性和概率性预测框架，以提高提前3-4周的极端高温预测能力。论文评估了Res-UNet模型在预测误差、覆盖范围和概率预测方面的性能，并将其与欧洲中期天气预报中心（EC）和经验分位数映射（QM）等方法进行了比较。研究结果表明，Res-UNet在较长时间的提前期内表现优于其他模型，能够更准确地预测极端高温事件的发生和消退。因此，该论文主要关注气象预测，而非大气环境遥感技术，如空气质量监测、卫星观测或大气成分分析。

authors: Shifeng Pan;Zhicong Yin;Yi Fan;Tingting Han;Mingkeng Duan;Huijun Wang
title: Sub-seasonal prediction of extreme high temperature over the Yangtze River Basin based on deep learning
abstract:
•A novel Res-UNet framework merges deterministic and probabilistic forecasts to boost 3–4 weeks extreme hot prediction. •Res-UNet outperforms ECMWF and QM in forecast error, fall area, and probabilistic forecast at 3–4 weeks lead times. •Res-UNet captures heatwave onset and decay 3 weeks ahead and surpasses other machine learning models in long-range extremes. 
 Extreme high temperatures frequently affect the densely populated Yangtze River Basin (YRB) in China, impacting livelihoods and ecosystems. However, predicting such events on a sub-seasonal scale remains challenging. This study develops an advanced deterministic and probabilistic forecasting framework based on the residual U-Net (Res-UNet) architecture, trained and validated from 2003 to 2018 and tested over 2019–2022 over the YRB. In deterministic forecast, Res-UNet substantially improves temporal correlation coefficient by 14 % compared to the European Center for Medium-range Weather Forecasts (EC) and empirical quantile mapping (QM) at the 3–4 weeks lead time. Notably, it achieves a probability of detection (POD) of 0.3, maintaining predictive skill where other models falter. For the probabilistic forecast, Res-UNet outperforms EC and QM at longer lead times, providing Brier Skill Score (BSS) and Continuous Ranked Probability Skill Score (CRPSS), with lower Brier Scores (BS), especially in Chongqing and Sichuan. During the extreme events of 2022, Res-UNet delivers high-confidence predictions of extreme high temperatures up to 3 weeks in advance. Furthermore, outperforming other machine learning models highlights its potential in enhancing sub-seasonal extreme high-temperature forecast.

authors: Xinshu Fu;Yanqing Gao;Jie Peng;Wei Guo;Yiwen Lu;Xiaofeng Wang;Hai Chu;Yanyan Zhang;Huiying Wang
title: Impacts of the urban heat island on the convective initiation and propagation of an extreme precipitation event in the coastal megacity of Shanghai
abstract:
•The UHI effect substantially augments the initiated convection by enhancing the “warm bubble” in Shanghai, albeit not directly triggering convection. •The UHI prolongs and intensifies convective activity over urban landscape during its back-building propagation. •As the UHI is attenuated, the urban-induced moisture deficiency dominates, leading to a suppression of convection over the urban area. 
 The impacts of urbanization, particularly through their complex interactions with synoptic-scale and orographic forcings, pose a great challenge to the accurate prediction of urban convective storms. On 28 July 2020, a convective storm occurs to the south of the Meiyu front, producing a localized and intense precipitation in the coastal megacity of Shanghai. To investigate urbanization impacts, particularly the urban heat island (UHI) effect, on such convective storm linked to Meiyu front and sea breeze circulation, comprehensive observational analysis and cloud-permitting (1 km) numerical simulations are conducted. Besides the favorable convective environments related to synoptic-scale forcings, a strong UHI surging to over 1.1 °C prior to precipitation is detected. It intensifies the “warm bubble” over Shanghai, sharpening its thermal contrasts with the Meiyu front's cold outflows and cool marine air, and increasing atmospheric instability. Subsequently, convergence over the eastern urban periphery is promoted to the west, forming an east-west oriented convergence line. A multicell line storm forms along it. As the convective system traverses the residual arid urban landscape, the UHI effect enhances the thermal contrast between its cold outflows and ambient environment, inducing the thermally driven convergence. This further facilitates the convective cell formation along the outflow boundary, resulting in the prolonged and intensified convective activity around the urban area. However, as the UHI is weakened, urban-induced moisture deficiency dominates, suppressing convection initiation over the urban area. It is implied that the pronounced UHI might promote convective activity in the vicinity of the urban center, even under the influence of synoptic-scale forcings.
